issue.title: dependency issues when installing from source

content.raw:
Which branch are you installing from source? Are you using [these installation instructions](http://gazebosim.org/tutorials/?tut=install#CompilingFromSource%28Ubuntu%29)? Those do list libogre-1.8-dev; this sounds like a problem with the installation instructions?

Here's the source to the [installation instructions](#!/osrf/gazebo_tutorials/src/912e8f8ba5f2/install/?at=default).
content.html:
Which branch are you installing from source? Are you using these installation instructions? Those do list libogre-1.8-dev; this sounds like a problem with the installation instructions?

Here's the source to the installation instructions.

issue.title: dependency issues when installing from source

content.raw:
I used branch 3.0, but these issues were present in earlier versions as well (~v2.x) as I remember. 

Under ubuntu 12.04 in order to get it to run, I install `libogre-dev` (instead of `libogre-1.8-dev`) which comes with version 1.7.4-3 and then cmake does not complain (this install is similar to the one for version 1.9).

Under ubuntu 13.04  I couldn't figure out a work-around.
content.html:
I used branch 3.0, but these issues were present in earlier versions as well (~v2.x) as I remember.

Under ubuntu 12.04 in order to get it to run, I install libogre-dev (instead of libogre-1.8-dev) which comes with version 1.7.4-3 and then cmake does not complain (this install is similar to the one for version 1.9).

Under ubuntu 13.04 I couldn't figure out a work-around.

issue.title: dependency issues when installing from source

content.raw:
Can you confirm my understanding:

1. You have Ubuntu 13.04
1. You want to use cegui, but cegui in 13.04 has a dependency on ogre.1.7.4?? (I don't believe this statement is correct).
1. You compile gazebo from source, and it segfaults.

It seems that 13.04, gazebo 3, and ogre-1.8 does not work for you? Or you're compiling against one version of ogre, and running against a different version.
content.html:
Can you confirm my understanding:

  1. You have Ubuntu 13.04
  2. You want to use cegui, but cegui in 13.04 has a dependency on ogre.1.7.4?? (I don't believe this statement is correct).
  3. You compile gazebo from source, and it segfaults.

It seems that 13.04, gazebo 3, and ogre-1.8 does not work for you? Or you're compiling against one version of ogre, and running against a different version.

issue.title: dependency issues when installing from source

content.raw:
I tried installing gazebo from source on two Ubuntu versions 12.04, 13.04 and these were the issues I encountered:

Installing [these](http://gazebosim.org/tutorials/?tut=install#InstallRequiredDependencies) required dependencies under 12.04 I got the following error:

```
#!

E: Couldn't find any package by regex 'libogre-1.8-dev'
```
As a workaround I installed `libogre-dev` instead, which comes with Ogre version 1.7.4-3 on which Gazebo can be built upon. This maybe should be added to the tutorial, if Ubuntu 12.04 is used install these libs.

=================

Using Ubuntu 13.04 all the required dependencies are installed, however with them two versions of Ogre are installed: `libogre-1.8-dev` gets version 1.8, and `libcegui-mk2-dev` version 1.7.4. This being the reason that I get the above mentioned [error](http://pastebin.com/Gk2f4VjK).  Line 6:

`/usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libOgreMain.so.1.7.4(+0x146333)[0x7f60992c4333]`

I did this weeks ago, maybe cegui does not pull this dependency with it anymore, but it was definitely the case, now I cannot re-run these steps to check if it's still happening.
content.html:
I tried installing gazebo from source on two Ubuntu versions 12.04, 13.04 and these were the issues I encountered:

Installing these required dependencies under 12.04 I got the following error:

E: Couldn't find any package by regex 'libogre-1.8-dev'

As a workaround I installed libogre-dev instead, which comes with Ogre version 1.7.4-3 on which Gazebo can be built upon. This maybe should be added to the tutorial, if Ubuntu 12.04 is used install these libs.

=================

Using Ubuntu 13.04 all the required dependencies are installed, however with them two versions of Ogre are installed: libogre-1.8-dev gets version 1.8, and libcegui-mk2-dev version 1.7.4. This being the reason that I get the above mentioned error. Line 6:

/usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libOgreMain.so.1.7.4(+0x146333)[0x7f60992c4333]

I did this weeks ago, maybe cegui does not pull this dependency with it anymore, but it was definitely the case, now I cannot re-run these steps to check if it's still happening.

issue.title: dependency issues when installing from source

content.raw:
Answering by parts:

1. In 12.04 we are using libogre-dev yes, which brings ogre 1.7.* series which is perfectly fine to run and compile gazebo. We should fix the tutorial.

2. In 13.04 both, ogre-1.7 (libogre-dev) or ogre-1.8 (libogre-1.8-dev) could be used. libogre-1.8-dev conflicts with raring version of libogre-dev so you can not have both versions at the same time if using packages. If you want to use cegui (optional), libcegui-mk2-0.7.6 depends on libogre-1.7.4 so it can not be installed together with libogre-1.8-dev but libogre-dev. How did you manage to get two versions installed at the same time? Am I missing something?

Thanks.
content.html:
Answering by parts:

  1. In 12.04 we are using libogre-dev yes, which brings ogre 1.7.* series which is perfectly fine to run and compile gazebo. We should fix the tutorial.

  2. In 13.04 both, ogre-1.7 (libogre-dev) or ogre-1.8 (libogre-1.8-dev) could be used. libogre-1.8-dev conflicts with raring version of libogre-dev so you can not have both versions at the same time if using packages. If you want to use cegui (optional), libcegui-mk2-0.7.6 depends on libogre-1.7.4 so it can not be installed together with libogre-1.8-dev but libogre-dev. How did you manage to get two versions installed at the same time? Am I missing something?

Thanks.

issue.title: dependency issues when installing from source

content.raw:
2. I got  the conflict by installing all the dependencies, how you just explained, `libogre-1.8-dev` and `libcegui-mk2-0.7.6`, and it does not complain when doing this, the error appears on runtime. 

So if I want to install cegui as well I should use the `libogre-dev` dependency. Got it :)
content.html:
1. I got the conflict by installing all the dependencies, how you just explained, libogre-1.8-dev and libcegui-mk2-0.7.6, and it does not complain when doing this, the error appears on runtime.

So if I want to install cegui as well I should use the libogre-dev dependency. Got it :)
